thread.title: Marty Ingels, husband of Shirley Jones, dies at 79
thread.title_full: Marty Ingels, husband of Shirley Jones, dies at 79

author: Tribune wire reports
title: Marty Ingels, husband of Shirley Jones, dies at 79
text:
Marty Ingels, husband of Shirley Jones, dies at 79 Shirley Jones, Marty Ingels Chris Carlson / AP 
In this Jan. 28, 2007 file photo, Shirley Jones left, and her husband Marty Ingels arrive at the 13th Annual Screen Actors Guild Awards in Los Angeles. 
In this Jan. 28, 2007 file photo, Shirley Jones left, and her husband Marty Ingels arrive at the 13th Annual Screen Actors Guild Awards in Los Angeles. (Chris Carlson / AP) Tribune wire reports Contact Reporter 
Marty Ingels, a raspy-voiced comedian, actor and talent agent who was married to singer and actress Shirley Jones for nearly 40 years, died Wednesday in Los Angeles. He was 79. 
Ingels died in the Tarzana neighborhood following complications from a stroke, according to a statement issued on behalf of Jones by her manager, Milt Suchin. 
"He often drove me crazy, but there's not a day I won't miss him and love him to my core," the actress said in the statement. 
Ingels was born Martin Ingerman in Brooklyn and later moved to Los Angeles. 
Beginning in the 1960s, Ingels appeared in some movies and a number of television show episodes, including "The Dick Van Dyke Show," ''The Phyllis Diller Show" and "Bewitched." Shirley Jones, Marty Ingels Wally Fong / AP 
In this Nov. 14, 1977 file photo, actress Shirley Jones and comedian Marty Ingles pose after their wedding in Bel Air, Calif. 
In this Nov. 14, 1977 file photo, actress Shirley Jones and comedian Marty Ingles pose after their wedding in Bel Air, Calif. (Wally Fong / AP) 
He co-starred with John Astin in the in the 1962-63 TV comedy "I'm Dickens, He's Fenster." 
Ingels also did voice work for hundreds of cartoons, commercials and video games. He voiced Pac-Man in the 1982 animated series. 
Ingels also ran a talent agency that booked movie stars such as John Wayne and Cary Grant for TV commercials. 
In 1974, Ingels met Shirley Jones, co-star of the 1970s TV hit "The Partridge Family," at a party at actor Michael Landon's home. 
"He pursued her relentlessly, and many in Jones' inner circle were initially put off by Ingels' gruff demeanor and brazen approach," according to the statement. "As he himself said, 'I was a Jewish kid from Brooklyn and she was Miss America. A lot of people never got that. But Shirley always did.' Elaine Woo 

His death Tuesday in Dunkirk, N.Y., was announced by Three Dog Night co-founder...
